blueprints.eli5: Itâ€™s a smart home recipe you can reuse and share with others.

service call.boss: A service call triggers a defined action on a smart device, like turning on a light or locking a door.

ospf.eli5: Itâ€™s like your router drawing a map of your network and sharing it with friends.

ospf.use_case: Using OSPF in a corporate LAN to reroute traffic dynamically when a link fails.

eigrp.eli5: Itâ€™s like a club of routers sharing tips about the best way to get places.
eigrp.boss: EIGRP is a Cisco protocol that helps routers share route info efficiently and quickly.
eigrp.sysadmin: Enhanced Interior Gateway Routing Protocol is Ciscoâ€™s hybrid routing protocol. Combines distance vector and link-state features. Supports unequal-cost paths.

rip.eli5: Itâ€™s like routers telling each other how far places areâ€”hop by hop.
rip.boss: RIP is a simple routing protocol that uses hop counts to determine paths.

is-is.eli5: Itâ€™s like OSPFâ€™s cousin, helping routers map the network efficiently.
is-is.boss: IS-IS is a link-state protocol similar to OSPF but often used by large providers.
is-is.sysadmin: Intermediate System to Intermediate System (IS-IS) uses a TLV-based format and supports large-scale multi-area networks. Runs directly on Layer 2.

mpls.eli5: Itâ€™s like fast lanes on the internet highway that skip traffic lights.

mpls.sysadmin: Multiprotocol Label Switching tags packets with labels for predetermined paths. Used in WANs and ISP networks to improve speed and QoS.
mpls.use_case: An enterprise using MPLS to ensure low-latency video conferencing between branches.

gre.eli5: Itâ€™s a tunnel your data can use to sneak across the internet.
gre.boss: GRE is a protocol that creates tunnels to carry other protocols across networks.

ipsec.eli5: Itâ€™s like sealing your message in an envelope before sending it across the internet.
ipsec.boss: IPSec secures internet traffic by encrypting and authenticating IP packets.
ipsec.sysadmin: Internet Protocol Security supports tunnel and transport modes using ESP and AH headers. Common in site-to-site and client VPNs.
ipsec.use_case: Securing a site-to-site VPN between branch offices using IPSec.

ssl/tls.eli5: Itâ€™s the lock icon in your browserâ€”protecting your messages online.
ssl/tls.boss: SSL/TLS encrypts communication between devices to ensure privacy and data integrity.
ssl/tls.sysadmin: Secure Sockets Layer (SSL) and its successor TLS use asymmetric encryption to secure web and email traffic. Required for HTTPS and many smart home APIs.
ssl/tls.use_case: Encrypting communications between your smart hub and cloud service using TLS.

http.eli5: Itâ€™s how your browser and websites talkâ€”like asking for a page and getting a reply.
http.boss: HTTP is the protocol used to request and send data over the web.

ftp.eli5: Itâ€™s how computers used to send each other files before fancy cloud stuff.

ftp.sysadmin: Runs over TCP ports 20 and 21. Supports active/passive modes. Lacks encryption unless paired with SSL (FTPS).

tftp.eli5: Itâ€™s a no-frills delivery guyâ€”fast but doesnâ€™t check if the package arrived.

ssh.eli5: Itâ€™s a secure walkie-talkie to talk to your computers remotely.

ssh.use_case: Remotely accessing your Raspberry Pi smart hub using SSH.

telnet.eli5: Itâ€™s like SSHâ€™s older sibling who doesnâ€™t care if others are eavesdropping.
telnet.boss: Telnet provides a way to remotely access devices, but without encryption.
telnet.sysadmin: Uses TCP port 23. Sends data in plain text. Mostly replaced by SSH. Still used for testing or legacy systems.
telnet.use_case: Connecting to an old switch via Telnet to configure its settings.

smtp.eli5: Itâ€™s the mail truck that delivers your outgoing email.
smtp.boss: SMTP is the protocol used to send emails from clients to servers.
smtp.sysadmin: Simple Mail Transfer Protocol uses TCP port 25 (or 587/465 for secure). Often used with authentication and TLS for secure sending.
smtp.use_case: Sending a smart home alert email using SMTP when a sensor triggers.

pop3.eli5: Itâ€™s like grabbing your mail and taking it homeâ€”you wonâ€™t see it again on the server.

pop3.sysadmin: Post Office Protocol v3 runs over TCP port 110 (or 995 for encrypted). Stores messages locally after download. Less useful for multi-device access.
pop3.use_case: Accessing your smart home alert inbox from an old device using POP3.

imap.eli5: Itâ€™s like leaving your mail on the server and checking it from anywhere.

imap.use_case: Accessing smart home alerts from multiple phones using IMAP.

snmp.eli5: Itâ€™s like your devices sending little status reports to a control center.

ntp.eli5: Itâ€™s how all your devices agree on what time it is.

ntp.use_case: Syncing your smart home hub to NTP so automations trigger on time.

radius.eli5: Itâ€™s like a bouncer that checks your ID before letting you into the network.

ldap.sysadmin: Lightweight Directory Access Protocol (TCP 389 or 636 for LDAPS) allows querying user/group records from a central directory, often Active Directory.

dns over https.eli5: It hides your internet phonebook lookups inside a locked envelope.

reverse proxy.sysadmin: Used in front of web servers. Handles SSL termination, load balancing, and caching. Common tools: Nginx, HAProxy, Traefik.

dns server.sysadmin: Uses root, TLD, and authoritative records to resolve queries. Can be local (Pi-hole, Unbound) or public (1.1.1.1, 8.8.8.8).

port forwarding.sysadmin: Used to expose services behind NAT. Maps external port to internal IP/port (e.g., 443 â†’ 192.168.1.10:8123). Must be secured against abuse.

layer 4.eli5: Itâ€™s the post office of the internetâ€”it makes sure your message gets there safely and in the right order.
layer 4.boss: Layer 4 is the transport layer that handles end-to-end connections using TCP and UDP.

lan.eli5: Think of a LAN like your home's Wi-Fi network. It's a private digital playground for all your gadgets to talk to each other.

wlan.boss: A WLAN (Wireless LAN) provides wireless network access within a local area, commonly using Wi-Fi to connect devices without physical cabling.
wlan.sysadmin: WLANs operate over 2.4GHz or 5GHz radio bands using standards like IEEE 802.11, managed by wireless access points with SSIDs, encryption, and MAC control.

san.eli5: A SAN is like a secret vault where all your files are stored and accessed super quickly by your computers.

san.sysadmin: SANs use protocols like Fibre Channel or iSCSI to offer block-level storage over a network, separating storage from compute for flexibility and scalability.

vlan.eli5: Imagine putting invisible walls inside your network to separate groups of devices even if they use the same cables.
vlan.boss: A VLAN (Virtual LAN) creates separate logical networks on the same physical hardware to improve security and reduce congestion.
vlan.sysadmin: VLANs tag Ethernet frames (using 802.1Q) to isolate broadcast domains at Layer 2, allowing network segmentation and policy control via managed switches.

vxlan.eli5: VXLAN is like adding zip codes on top of addresses so you can organize a giant digital city without traffic jams.
vxlan.boss: VXLAN (Virtual Extensible LAN) allows network virtualization across large-scale data centers by extending Layer 2 segments over Layer 3 infrastructure.

sd-wan.eli5: SD-WAN is like giving your GPS directions to your data so it always takes the fastest, cheapest, and safest route.

sd-wan.sysadmin: SD-WAN abstracts WAN transport using software-defined overlays, dynamic path selection, traffic shaping, and centralized orchestration for performance, cost, and security benefits.

vpn.boss: A VPN (Virtual Private Network) encrypts your internet traffic and routes it through a secure server, protecting privacy and enabling remote access.
vpn.sysadmin: VPNs create encrypted tunnels (using IPSec, SSL, or WireGuard) between endpoints, masking traffic from third parties and enforcing access control.
vpn.use_case: A remote employee connects to their companyâ€™s network using a VPN to access internal files securely.

2.4ghz.eli5: 2.4GHz is like the country roadâ€”slower but it goes longer distances and through more walls.
2.4ghz.boss: 2.4GHz is a widely used Wi-Fi band known for its long range and compatibility, though itâ€™s more prone to interference.

wep.eli5: WEP is like locking your door with a paperclipâ€”it looks secure but anyone can break in.

ssid.eli5: SSID is just your Wi-Fiâ€™s nameâ€”the label you see when picking a network to connect to.

ssid broadcast.eli5: Itâ€™s like shouting your Wi-Fi name to the neighborhood so people know itâ€™s there.

mac filtering.eli5: MAC filtering is like a bouncer checking a guest listâ€”only approved devices can get in.

wifi analyzer.use_case: A homeowner uses a WiFi Analyzer to move their router away from neighbor interference.

speed test.boss: Speed tests measure your internet connectionâ€™s upload, download, and latency to help evaluate network performance.

packet sniffer.eli5: A packet sniffer is like listening in on every digital whisper in your network.

port scanner.eli5: A port scanner is like knocking on every door of a building to see which ones are unlocked.
port scanner.boss: Port scanners check which network ports are open on a system to discover running services or potential vulnerabilities.

latency.eli5: Latency is the time it takes for your message to say 'hi' and get a 'hello' back.
latency.boss: Latency is the delay between sending a request and receiving a responseâ€”lower latency means faster responsiveness.
latency.sysadmin: Latency measures round-trip time (RTT) in milliseconds, affected by physical distance, routing paths, and network congestion.
latency.use_case: A gamer complains about lag because of high latency between their PC and the game server.

throughput.eli5: Throughput is how much stuff you can push through a pipe every second.
throughput.boss: Throughput measures the actual amount of data successfully transferred over a network in a given time.
throughput.sysadmin: Throughput is calculated in bits per second (bps), reflecting real-world bandwidth after accounting for overhead, errors, and retransmissions.
throughput.use_case: An engineer monitors throughput to ensure video streams stay smooth under peak load.

jitter.eli5: Jitter is like traffic jams that come and goâ€”making your ride bumpy and inconsistent.
jitter.boss: Jitter is the variation in delay between data packets, which can cause issues in voice and video calls.
jitter.sysadmin: Jitter refers to the variability in packet arrival times, measured in milliseconds; high jitter disrupts time-sensitive applications like VoIP.
jitter.use_case: A VoIP call has poor quality due to jitter causing uneven audio delivery.

packet loss.eli5: Packet loss is when your message gets lost in the mail and never arrives.
packet loss.boss: Packet loss happens when some data sent over a network never reaches its destination, hurting performance.
packet loss.sysadmin: Packet loss occurs when packets are dropped due to congestion, errors, or hardware failuresâ€”measured as a percentage of total traffic.
packet loss.use_case: A streaming service buffers because of packet loss between the client and CDN.

bandwidth.eli5: Bandwidth is the size of the roadâ€”bigger roads can carry more cars at once.
bandwidth.boss: Bandwidth is the maximum capacity of a network link to transmit data, usually measured in Mbps or Gbps.
bandwidth.sysadmin: Bandwidth defines the theoretical upper limit of data transfer on a network link, independent of actual throughput or latency.
bandwidth.use_case: An office upgrades its bandwidth to 1 Gbps to support video conferencing for all staff.

ping time.eli5: Ping time is how fast you get a reply after saying â€˜hiâ€™ to another computer.
ping time.boss: Ping time measures how long it takes for data to travel to a destination and back, indicating connection responsiveness.
ping time.sysadmin: Ping time is the round-trip delay reported by ICMP Echo Request/Reply packets, often used as a basic performance test.
ping time.use_case: A speed test shows a 12ms ping time, indicating fast responsiveness for gaming.

isp.eli5: Your ISP is the company that connects your home to the internet highway.
isp.boss: An ISP (Internet Service Provider) is a company that delivers internet access to homes and businesses.
isp.sysadmin: An ISP assigns public IPs, manages upstream routing, and handles DNS, peering, and bandwidth provisioning for end users.
isp.use_case: A small business switches ISPs to get higher upload speeds for video conferencing.

as number.eli5: An AS number is like a license plate for an internet providerâ€”it shows who owns a piece of the internet.
as number.boss: An AS (Autonomous System) Number uniquely identifies large networks on the internet for routing traffic between them.
as number.sysadmin: ASN is used in BGP to establish routing policies between ISPs and large enterprises; public ASNs are assigned by RIRs.
as number.use_case: A hosting provider uses its own AS number to peer directly with multiple ISPs via BGP.

peering.eli5: Peering is like two neighbors agreeing to share their roads for free.
peering.boss: Peering is when two networks agree to exchange traffic directly without paying a third party.
peering.sysadmin: Peering enables Autonomous Systems to exchange traffic via BGP at IXPs, improving performance and reducing transit costs.
peering.use_case: A content provider peers with a local ISP to serve videos faster to nearby users.

transit provider.eli5: A transit provider is like the toll highwayâ€”networks pay it to get around the internet.
transit provider.boss: Transit providers are companies that sell access to the broader internet by routing your traffic through their networks.
transit provider.sysadmin: Transit providers offer global internet connectivity via tier-1/2 networks, advertising customer routes using BGP in exchange for fees.
transit provider.use_case: A data center uses multiple transit providers to ensure reliable global connectivity.

cdn.eli5: A CDN puts copies of websites near you so they load super fastâ€”like fast food chains for the internet.
cdn.boss: A CDN (Content Delivery Network) caches and serves content from edge servers close to users, speeding up load times and reducing latency.
cdn.sysadmin: CDNs replicate static and dynamic content across edge nodes globally, improving availability, performance, and reducing origin server load.
cdn.use_case: A news site uses a CDN to handle traffic spikes and improve load times during breaking events.

edge server.eli5: Edge servers are mini-helpers stationed near users so content gets delivered faster.
edge server.boss: Edge servers deliver cached or processed content close to users, minimizing latency and improving app performance.
edge server.sysadmin: Edge servers sit at the network perimeter, handling caching, authentication, or compute offloading for faster response in CDNs and zero-trust setups.
edge server.use_case: A streaming platform uses edge servers to deliver HD video with minimal buffering.

caching proxy.eli5: A caching proxy is like a local libraryâ€”it keeps copies of popular websites so you donâ€™t have to go far to get them.
caching proxy.boss: A caching proxy stores frequently accessed data to reduce internet usage and speed up web performance.
caching proxy.sysadmin: Caching proxies intercept HTTP/S requests, serving cached responses when valid to reduce latency and backend load.
caching proxy.use_case: A school uses a caching proxy to reduce bandwidth usage for commonly visited educational sites.

ipv6 tunneling.eli5: IPv6 tunneling is like sending a letter in an envelope that speaks the old language (IPv4).
ipv6 tunneling.boss: IPv6 tunneling lets IPv6 traffic travel across networks that only understand IPv4 by wrapping it inside IPv4 packets.
ipv6 tunneling.sysadmin: IPv6 tunneling encapsulates IPv6 packets within IPv4 headers using protocols like 6to4, Teredo, or ISATAP, enabling transition on dual-stack networks.
ipv6 tunneling.use_case: A business enables IPv6 tunneling to support next-gen devices across its IPv4-only backbone.

teredo.eli5: Teredo is a translator that helps IPv6 messages travel across IPv4 without anyone noticing.
teredo.boss: Teredo is a tunneling protocol that allows IPv6 connectivity across NAT-enabled IPv4 networks.
teredo.sysadmin: Teredo encapsulates IPv6 packets in UDP over IPv4, providing limited IPv6 support through NAT traversal, often used in Windows environments.
teredo.use_case: A remote user uses Teredo to connect to an IPv6-only service from their home IPv4 NAT router.

6to4.eli5: 6to4 is like packing an IPv6 message inside an IPv4 box so it can go through old routes.
6to4.boss: 6to4 is an automatic method for sending IPv6 traffic across IPv4 networks without manual tunnels.
6to4.sysadmin: 6to4 encapsulates IPv6 packets inside IPv4 (protocol 41), using special 2002::/16 address blocks and relay routers.
6to4.use_case: An early IPv6 adopter configures 6to4 to test connectivity before native IPv6 support is available.

nat64.eli5: NAT64 is like a bilingual switchboardâ€”it lets IPv6-only devices talk to IPv4-only ones.
nat64.boss: NAT64 lets IPv6-only devices access IPv4 services by translating requests between the two IP formats.
nat64.sysadmin: NAT64 uses address translation and protocol conversion to allow IPv6 clients to connect to IPv4 servers, often paired with DNS64.
nat64.use_case: A mobile carrier uses NAT64 to support IPv6-only phones connecting to legacy IPv4 websites.

dns64.eli5: DNS64 gives IPv6 devices fake IPv6 addresses so they can reach IPv4 services.
dns64.boss: DNS64 generates synthetic AAAA records for IPv6-only clients trying to reach IPv4-only servers.
dns64.sysadmin: DNS64 intercepts DNS queries and responds with translated IPv6 addresses, enabling NAT64 to route requests correctly.
dns64.use_case: A DNS server uses DNS64 to help IPv6 IoT devices access cloud APIs that only support IPv4.

network stack.eli5: The network stack is like a relay team passing your data baton from one layer to another until it reaches the internet.
network stack.boss: A network stack is the set of software layers that handle all aspects of networkingâ€”from physical connections to application-level data.
network stack.sysadmin: The network stack includes protocol layers like TCP/IP or OSI, handling encapsulation, routing, error checking, and delivery from Layer 1 to Layer 7.
network stack.use_case: A developer debugs a faulty app by analyzing how packets flow through the system's network stack.

osi model.eli5: The OSI Model is like a 7-layer cakeâ€”each layer adds something tasty to help get your message across.
osi model.boss: The OSI Model is a framework that divides network functions into seven layers to simplify design and troubleshooting.
osi model.sysadmin: OSI layers range from Layer 1 (Physical) to Layer 7 (Application), each handling specific tasks in network communication.
osi model.use_case: A trainer uses the OSI model to teach junior techs where problems can occur in a network path.

distribution switch.eli5: A distribution switch is like a traffic light that controls how smaller roads connect to highways.
distribution switch.boss: Distribution switches sit between access switches and core networks, helping aggregate and route local traffic upward.
distribution switch.sysadmin: In a three-tier network, the distribution layer provides inter-VLAN routing, redundancy, and policy enforcement between access and core switches.
distribution switch.use_case: A university campus installs distribution switches to route data between departmental networks.

access switch.eli5: An access switch is where your computer plugs into the networkâ€”like your buildingâ€™s front desk.
access switch.boss: Access switches connect end-user devices to the network, assigning them to VLANs and linking them to higher-level switches.
access switch.sysadmin: Access switches operate at Layer 2, provide PoE, port security, and VLAN accessâ€”usually deployed at the network edge.
access switch.use_case: An office deploys access switches on each floor to connect workstations and IP phones.

aggregation layer.eli5: The aggregation layer is like a funnelâ€”it gathers local traffic before sending it up the chain.
aggregation layer.boss: The aggregation layer in networking consolidates traffic from access switches and applies routing, filtering, and policy before forwarding it to the core.
aggregation layer.sysadmin: This layer implements VLAN routing, ACLs, QoS, and redundancy, forming the middle tier in hierarchical networks.
aggregation layer.use_case: An enterprise network uses the aggregation layer to centralize policies for multiple departments.

linkerd.eli5: Linkerd is like a bodyguard for your appâ€™s messagesâ€”it makes sure theyâ€™re safe, fast, and reach the right place.
linkerd.boss: Linkerd is a service mesh that adds reliability, security, and visibility to microservice communications without modifying code.
linkerd.sysadmin: Linkerd runs as sidecar proxies or a data plane in Kubernetes, managing mTLS, retries, load balancing, and metrics across services.
linkerd.use_case: A DevOps team adds Linkerd to a Kubernetes cluster to secure and monitor internal API calls.

srv record.eli5: An SRV record is like a VIP passâ€”it tells you where to find a specific service like chat or video calls.
srv record.boss: SRV (Service) records in DNS specify the host and port for services like VoIP, LDAP, or SIP under a domain.
srv record.sysadmin: SRV records include priority, weight, port, and target, allowing service-specific lookups for protocols like _sip._tcp.example.com.
srv record.use_case: A VoIP provider uses SRV records to direct clients to the correct SIP server and port.

ns record.eli5: NS records are like signpostsâ€”they tell your computer where to ask about a websiteâ€™s info.
ns record.boss: NS (Name Server) records point to the authoritative DNS servers for a domain.
ns record.sysadmin: NS records define which DNS servers are authoritative for a domain zone, and must match with glue records at the registrar.
ns record.use_case: A domain owner updates their NS records to point to their new hosting providerâ€™s DNS.

tcp/ip model.eli5: The TCP/IP model is like a mail service blueprintâ€”it explains how your message goes from your house to your friendâ€™s.
tcp/ip model.boss: The TCP/IP model breaks down internet communication into four layers, from physical connections to applications.
tcp/ip model.sysadmin: TCP/IP consists of Link, Internet, Transport, and Application layers, forming the foundation of internet protocol suite and replacing OSI in practice.
tcp/ip model.use_case: Network instructors use the TCP/IP model to explain real-world protocol mapping like IP and TCP.

mac table.eli5: A MAC table is like a doormanâ€™s listâ€”it tells the switch which door to send a message through.
mac table.boss: A MAC table in a switch maps device MAC addresses to specific switch ports, enabling proper data delivery.
mac table.sysadmin: Switches build a MAC address table by learning source addresses on incoming frames, storing them with corresponding interfaces for unicast forwarding.
mac table.use_case: A switch uses its MAC table to send packets only to the correct device instead of flooding all ports.

routing table.eli5: A routing table is like a GPSâ€”it tells your router the best path to send data.
routing table.boss: A routing table lists paths for sending network traffic, telling routers where to forward data based on destination IP addresses.
routing table.sysadmin: Routing tables contain routes, next-hop addresses, interface bindings, and metrics, used by routers and hosts to make packet-forwarding decisions.
routing table.use_case: An admin reviews the routing table to troubleshoot why a server can't reach a remote network.

arp table.eli5: An ARP table is like a contact list that links peopleâ€™s names to their phone numbersâ€”except it maps IPs to MACs.
arp table.boss: An ARP table maps IP addresses to hardware MAC addresses so devices can find each other on a local network.
arp table.sysadmin: The ARP cache stores dynamic or static IP-to-MAC address mappings, resolved via ARP requests on Layer 2.
arp table.use_case: A sysadmin clears a stale ARP table entry that's preventing proper device communication.

cam table.eli5: A CAM table is like a delivery guideâ€”it helps your switch remember where to send which package.
cam table.boss: A CAM (Content Addressable Memory) table helps switches quickly map MAC addresses to switch ports.
cam table.sysadmin: The CAM table stores fixed-length MAC address entries indexed by interface and VLAN, allowing fast Layer 2 switching.
cam table.use_case: A technician uses the CAM table to trace a MAC address to a physical port on a switch.

network segmentation.eli5: Itâ€™s like putting different groups into different rooms so they donâ€™t all shout over each other.
network segmentation.boss: Network segmentation separates traffic into different parts of a network to improve security and performance.
network segmentation.sysadmin: Segmentation divides networks using VLANs, subnets, or firewalls to limit broadcast domains and enforce security policies.
network segmentation.use_case: A company segments its network to isolate guest Wi-Fi from internal business systems.

subnetting.eli5: Subnetting is like slicing a big pizza into smaller pieces so everyone gets their share.
subnetting.boss: Subnetting divides a network into smaller segments to manage traffic and organize devices.
subnetting.sysadmin: Subnetting splits IP ranges using subnet masks (e.g., /24, /26) to create efficient address allocation and logical separation.
subnetting.use_case: An IT team subnets a /16 network into /24 blocks to separate departments by IP range.

supernetting.eli5: Supernetting is the opposite of subnettingâ€”it's merging small pieces into one big chunk.
supernetting.boss: Supernetting combines smaller networks into a larger one, simplifying routing tables and management.
supernetting.sysadmin: Supernetting (CIDR aggregation) merges multiple subnets into one larger route, reducing routing table size and overhead.
supernetting.use_case: An ISP uses supernetting to summarize customer routes before advertising them via BGP.

vlsm.eli5: VLSM is like cutting custom-sized pizza slices depending on who's eatingâ€”small ones for kids, big ones for adults.
vlsm.boss: VLSM (Variable Length Subnet Masking) allows different subnet sizes within the same network to optimize IP usage.
vlsm.sysadmin: VLSM uses non-uniform subnet masks (e.g., /30, /28, /24) to allocate IPs based on host count, improving efficiency.
vlsm.use_case: A network engineer uses VLSM to allocate just enough IPs to each branch office without wasting addresses.

network policy.eli5: A network policy is like a rulebook that says who can talk to who on the playground.
network policy.boss: Network policies define rules for what devices or apps can access across the network, improving security and control.
network policy.sysadmin: Network policies enforce access controls, bandwidth limits, or isolation rules using ACLs, firewalls, or Kubernetes network policy objects.
network policy.use_case: A DevOps team applies network policies in Kubernetes to prevent unauthorized cross-pod communication.

zero trust network.eli5: Itâ€™s like not trusting anyone at the doorâ€”you check ID every time, even if theyâ€™ve been in before.
zero trust network.boss: A Zero Trust Network assumes no user or device is trusted by default, requiring verification at every step.
zero trust network.sysadmin: Zero Trust enforces continuous authentication, least privilege access, microsegmentation, and monitoring to prevent lateral threats.
zero trust network.use_case: A healthcare organization implements Zero Trust to ensure only verified devices access patient data.

acl.eli5: An ACL is like a guest listâ€”youâ€™re either allowed in or youâ€™re not.
acl.boss: An Access Control List (ACL) defines which users or devices can access specific parts of a network or system.
acl.sysadmin: ACLs are rule sets applied on routers or firewalls to permit or deny traffic based on IP, port, or protocol.
acl.use_case: A firewall uses an ACL to block all inbound SSH access from the internet.

firewall rules.eli5: Firewall rules are like doormenâ€”they check who's trying to come in or go out and decide whether to let them.
firewall rules.boss: Firewall rules control which network traffic is allowed or blocked, based on security policies.
firewall rules.sysadmin: Firewall rules match on protocol, IP, port, and direction to filter traffic at Layer 3/4 or Layer 7 depending on the firewall type.
firewall rules.use_case: A cloud engineer updates firewall rules to allow HTTPS but block FTP on a web server.

security groups.eli5: Security groups are like bubble shieldsâ€”only traffic with the right key can get in or out.
security groups.boss: Security groups are virtual firewalls for cloud resources, controlling traffic based on rules you define.
security groups.sysadmin: In cloud platforms like AWS or Azure, security groups are stateful firewalls assigned to resources, filtering inbound/outbound traffic based on IP, port, and protocol.
security groups.use_case: A DevOps engineer applies a security group to an EC2 instance to block all ports except 22 and 443.

network zones.eli5: Network zones are like color-coded roomsâ€”each one has different rules about what can go in or out.
network zones.boss: Network zones segment an environment into logical areas like public, internal, and DMZ, each with specific access policies.
network zones.sysadmin: Zones define trust boundaries and are used in firewall configs or SDN to enforce policy between different types of systems (e.g., internal, guest, partner).
network zones.use_case: A smart home router uses zones to isolate IoT devices from personal computers.

proxy bypass.eli5: Proxy bypass is like taking the side road instead of the toll road to get where you're going.
proxy bypass.boss: Proxy bypass allows certain traffic to go directly to the internet without passing through a proxy server.
proxy bypass.sysadmin: Proxy bypass rules exclude specific domains or IPs from proxy routing, typically set via PAC files or firewall policies.
proxy bypass.use_case: A developer sets proxy bypass rules to access local test servers without going through the corporate proxy.

split tunneling.eli5: Split tunneling lets you use two roads at onceâ€”one for private stuff and one for regular internet.
split tunneling.boss: Split tunneling lets VPN users access the internet directly while keeping internal traffic encrypted through the tunnel.
split tunneling.sysadmin: Split tunneling routes only select traffic (e.g., internal IP ranges) through the VPN, while other traffic bypasses it to conserve bandwidth.
split tunneling.use_case: A remote employee uses split tunneling to browse YouTube while connected to the company VPN for work apps.

geo-blocking.eli5: Geo-blocking is like a website saying 'sorry, not available in your country.'
geo-blocking.boss: Geo-blocking restricts access to content or services based on the userâ€™s geographic location.
geo-blocking.sysadmin: Geo-blocking uses IP geolocation to block or allow traffic from specific countries, often implemented via firewalls or CDN settings.
geo-blocking.use_case: A media company geo-blocks streaming content to comply with licensing restrictions by country.

content filtering.eli5: Content filtering is like a digital bouncerâ€”it blocks things youâ€™re not supposed to see or do.
content filtering.boss: Content filtering limits access to certain websites, services, or keywords to enforce usage policies.
content filtering.sysadmin: Filtering tools inspect HTTP/S traffic, DNS queries, or keywords to block categories like social media, gambling, or malware domains.
content filtering.use_case: A school uses content filtering to block adult websites and YouTube during class hours.

deep packet inspection.eli5: DPI is like opening every letter in the mailroom to check its contents before delivery.
deep packet inspection.boss: Deep Packet Inspection (DPI) inspects data packets beyond just headers to analyze, block, or prioritize traffic.
deep packet inspection.sysadmin: DPI examines packet payloads for protocol violations, malware signatures, or data leakage, often used in firewalls, IDS/IPS, and QoS systems.
deep packet inspection.use_case: An enterprise firewall uses DPI to detect and block P2P file sharing applications.

nac.eli5: NAC is like checking guests at the door to make sure theyâ€™re healthy before letting them in.
nac.boss: Network Access Control (NAC) ensures only authorized and compliant devices connect to the network.
nac.sysadmin: NAC systems evaluate endpoint posture (e.g., antivirus, OS version) and enforce access policies via 802.1X or inline gateways.
nac.use_case: A hospital uses NAC to block unpatched laptops from connecting to patient data networks.

802.1x.eli5: 802.1X is like a security gate that checks your ID before letting you onto the network.
802.1x.boss: 802.1X is a network access control protocol that authenticates users or devices before granting network access.
802.1x.sysadmin: 802.1X uses EAP over LAN (EAPOL) to facilitate authentication between clients, switches or access points (authenticators), and a RADIUS server.
802.1x.use_case: A university uses 802.1X to ensure only students and staff can connect to its secure Wi-Fi.

captive portal.eli5: A captive portal is that screen you see at hotels or airports asking you to sign in before getting Wi-Fi.
captive portal.boss: Captive portals redirect users to a login page before granting internet access, often used in public or guest networks.
captive portal.sysadmin: Captive portals intercept HTTP traffic until authentication (voucher, login, or acceptance) is completed, typically via DHCP and DNS tricks.
captive portal.use_case: A cafÃ© uses a captive portal to display terms of service before allowing customers onto its Wi-Fi.

wireless roaming.eli5: Wireless roaming is like your phone quietly switching cell towers so your call doesnâ€™t drop.
wireless roaming.boss: Wireless roaming allows a device to stay connected to a Wi-Fi network while moving between access points.
wireless roaming.sysadmin: Roaming enables seamless client handoff between overlapping access points based on signal strength and metrics like RSSI or 802.11k/v/r support.
wireless roaming.use_case: A user walks through their office and stays connected as their laptop switches access points via wireless roaming.

seamless handoff.eli5: Itâ€™s like passing the Wi-Fi batonâ€”you donâ€™t even notice when it switches access points.
seamless handoff.boss: Seamless handoff lets a device switch between access points on the same network without dropping the connection.
seamless handoff.sysadmin: With support for 802.11r and fast BSS transition, seamless handoff allows quick reauthentication and reassociation during AP transitions.
seamless handoff.use_case: A video call stays active on a phone even while walking from one side of the house to the other.

beamforming.eli5: Beamforming is like aiming a flashlightâ€”Wi-Fi gets focused in your direction instead of shining everywhere.
beamforming.boss: Beamforming is a Wi-Fi technology that directs signals toward your device, improving speed and range.
beamforming.sysadmin: Beamforming uses phased antenna arrays to focus RF signals in the direction of connected clients, reducing interference and boosting signal strength.
beamforming.use_case: A gaming console gets a stronger signal thanks to beamforming on the router optimizing coverage in that direction.

mimo.eli5: MIMO is like giving your Wi-Fi extra arms so it can carry more data at once.
mimo.boss: MIMO (Multiple Input, Multiple Output) allows Wi-Fi routers to transmit and receive data over multiple antennas for better performance.
mimo.sysadmin: MIMO uses multiple spatial streams on transmit and receive sides to increase throughput and reliability on 802.11n/ac/ax networks.
mimo.use_case: A smart TV benefits from faster streaming thanks to MIMO-enabled Wi-Fi providing better signal capacity.

mu-mimo.eli5: MU-MIMO is like a chef cooking multiple meals at once instead of one at a time.
mu-mimo.boss: MU-MIMO allows Wi-Fi routers to serve multiple devices at the same time without slowing down.
mu-mimo.sysadmin: Multi-User MIMO splits spatial streams across multiple clients, improving efficiency in environments with many concurrent users (802.11ac/ax).
mu-mimo.use_case: A household with smart TVs, phones, and laptops uses MU-MIMO to stream and browse without lag.

mesh backhaul.eli5: Mesh backhaul is like a private hallway between Wi-Fi nodesâ€”they use it to talk to each other without slowing your devices down.
mesh backhaul.boss: Mesh backhaul is the communication link between mesh Wi-Fi nodes, which can be wired or wireless.
mesh backhaul.sysadmin: Backhaul refers to inter-node communication in mesh systems, using dedicated 5GHz/6GHz bands or Ethernet for optimal performance.
mesh backhaul.use_case: A home uses dedicated mesh backhaul over 5GHz to keep device speeds fast even when far from the main router.

channel width.eli5: Channel width is like a highway lane sizeâ€”wider lanes mean more traffic, but more interference too.
channel width.boss: Channel width determines how much data a Wi-Fi signal can carry, balancing speed and stability.
channel width.sysadmin: Wi-Fi supports 20, 40, 80, and 160 MHz widths; wider channels increase throughput but risk more overlap and interference.
channel width.use_case: A user reduces channel width to 20 MHz to avoid Wi-Fi interference in a congested apartment complex.

dfs channels.eli5: DFS channels are like special backroadsâ€”less crowded but you have to watch out for airplanes.
dfs channels.boss: DFS (Dynamic Frequency Selection) channels offer more Wi-Fi spectrum but must avoid radar interference.
dfs channels.sysadmin: DFS enables access to 5GHz frequencies shared with radar systems, requiring APs to scan and vacate when radar is detected.
dfs channels.use_case: A mesh system uses DFS channels to reduce congestion and improve Wi-Fi speeds in urban environments.

home networking.eli5: Home networking is how all your gadgetsâ€”TVs, tablets, lightsâ€”talk to each other and the internet.
home networking.boss: Home networking connects personal devices to each other and the internet, enabling smart features and shared access.
home networking.sysadmin: A home network typically uses a router with LAN/WAN ports, DHCP, NAT, and Wi-Fi to manage IP addressing and local traffic routing.
home networking.use_case: A user sets up a home network to share a printer, stream movies, and control smart lights.

soho router.eli5: A SOHO router is the Wi-Fi box in your house that keeps everything connected.
soho router.boss: A SOHO (Small Office/Home Office) router provides internet access and local networking for homes and small businesses.
soho router.sysadmin: SOHO routers offer NAT, DHCP, basic firewall, and wireless capabilities, often in one device with consumer-grade features.
soho router.use_case: A remote worker configures a SOHO router to separate work and personal devices into different networks.

mesh wi-fi system.eli5: A mesh Wi-Fi system is like having multiple routers working together to cover your whole house with signal.
mesh wi-fi system.boss: Mesh Wi-Fi uses multiple nodes to provide seamless and consistent wireless coverage across large areas.
mesh wi-fi system.sysadmin: Mesh systems distribute wireless access points with coordinated backhaul and client steering, often auto-configured and app-managed.
mesh wi-fi system.use_case: A homeowner installs a mesh Wi-Fi system to eliminate dead zones in their basement and backyard.

ethernet backhaul.eli5: Ethernet backhaul is like running a cable behind the scenes so your mesh nodes donâ€™t rely on Wi-Fi to talk.
ethernet backhaul.boss: Ethernet backhaul connects mesh Wi-Fi nodes with physical cables to improve speed and reliability.
ethernet backhaul.sysadmin: Ethernet backhaul offloads inter-node traffic from wireless to wired, reducing latency and freeing up wireless bandwidth.
ethernet backhaul.use_case: A user connects mesh nodes via Ethernet to increase throughput and avoid wireless congestion.

powerline networking.eli5: Powerline networking sends internet through your homeâ€™s electrical wiring like magic plumbing for data.
powerline networking.boss: Powerline networking allows you to use your home's power lines to transmit network data between adapters.
powerline networking.sysadmin: Adapters convert Ethernet traffic to signals sent over AC wiring, usually supporting up to 1 Gbps under ideal conditions.
powerline networking.use_case: A gamer uses powerline adapters to get wired speeds without running long Ethernet cables.

moca.eli5: MoCA sends your internet through the TV cables already in your wallsâ€”no drilling needed.

availability.eli5: Availability means your stuff is always online and working when you need it.
availability.boss: Availability ensures systems and data are accessible to users and applications whenever required.
availability.sysadmin: Redundancy, failover, backups, and load balancing maintain uptime and reduce single points of failure.
availability.use_case: A business uses redundant servers to guarantee availability of its web platform 24/7.

risk.eli5: Risk is the chance something bad could happen and mess things up.
risk.boss: Risk in IT refers to the potential for a threat to exploit a vulnerability and negatively impact operations or data.
risk.sysadmin: Risk is calculated by combining threat likelihood and impact, often mitigated through controls and policies.
risk.use_case: A CISO evaluates risk before deploying a new cloud application with customer data.

threat.eli5: A threat is anything that could cause troubleâ€”like a hacker, virus, or even a power outage.
threat.boss: A threat is a potential cause of harm to systems, data, or operations.
threat.sysadmin: Threats can be internal or external, intentional (e.g., malware) or unintentional (e.g., hardware failure).
threat.use_case: An audit identifies phishing as a top threat to employee credentials.

vulnerability.eli5: A vulnerability is a weak spot in your armorâ€”something that could let the bad guys in.
vulnerability.boss: Vulnerabilities are flaws or gaps in a system that could be exploited by threats to cause harm.
vulnerability.sysadmin: They include unpatched software, misconfigurations, weak passwords, or exposed portsâ€”often addressed via vulnerability scanning.
vulnerability.use_case: An outdated CMS plugin creates a vulnerability that gets flagged during a security scan.

exploit.eli5: An exploit is a trick someone uses to break into a computer using a known weakness.
exploit.boss: Exploits are techniques used by attackers to take advantage of vulnerabilities and breach systems.
exploit.sysadmin: An exploit can be a script, payload, or command that leverages a software or hardware flaw to gain unauthorized access.
exploit.use_case: A cybercriminal uses an exploit targeting a zero-day browser bug to hijack sessions.

attack surface.eli5: Your attack surface is like all the windows and doors in a house where a burglar might get in.
attack surface.boss: An attack surface includes all points where an unauthorized user could try to enter or extract data from your system.
attack surface.sysadmin: It spans endpoints, ports, APIs, user accounts, and codeâ€”minimized via hardening, segmentation, and monitoring.
attack surface.use_case: A pen tester maps an appâ€™s attack surface before launching scans and probes.

attack vector.eli5: An attack vector is the path a hacker takes to sneak into your digital home.
attack vector.boss: An attack vector is the method or route an attacker uses to exploit a system or steal data.
attack vector.sysadmin: Common vectors include phishing, malware, open ports, weak credentials, and social engineering tactics.
attack vector.use_case: A security team blocks USB ports to eliminate a physical attack vector for malware delivery.

zero-day exploit.eli5: A zero-day exploit is like a surprise attackâ€”no one sees it coming because the flaw hasnâ€™t been fixed yet.
zero-day exploit.boss: A zero-day exploit targets a vulnerability thatâ€™s unknown to the vendor and has no patch available.
zero-day exploit.sysadmin: Zero-days are exploited immediately upon discovery, often traded on the black market before disclosure or mitigation.
zero-day exploit.use_case: A security firm rushes to isolate systems after discovering a zero-day in remote desktop software.

malware.eli5: Malware is like digital bad guys sneaking into your computer to cause trouble.
malware.boss: Malware is malicious software designed to harm, steal, or disrupt computers and networks.
malware.sysadmin: Types include viruses, worms, trojans, ransomware, and spywareâ€”delivered via downloads, phishing, or infected media.
malware.use_case: A USB drive infects a PC with malware that steals browser credentials.

virus.eli5: A virus is like a bad app that copies itself and spreads to other computers.
virus.boss: A virus is a type of malware that replicates and spreads between systems, often through files or emails.
virus.sysadmin: Viruses insert malicious code into host programs and trigger when those programs runâ€”sometimes corrupting or deleting data.
virus.use_case: An old spreadsheet macro carries a virus that corrupts documents on infected machines.

worm.eli5: A worm is like a virus that doesnâ€™t need a rideâ€”it travels and spreads all by itself.
worm.boss: A worm is a self-replicating malware that spreads across networks without needing a host file or user action.
worm.sysadmin: Worms exploit vulnerabilities or use brute force to propagate through open ports, often consuming bandwidth and system resources.
worm.use_case: A worm infects IoT devices using weak Telnet credentials, forming part of a botnet.

trojan horse.eli5: A Trojan looks helpful, but itâ€™s hiding something nasty insideâ€”like a fake app with a virus.
trojan horse.boss: A Trojan Horse is malware disguised as legitimate software that tricks users into installing it.
trojan horse.sysadmin: Trojans often deliver backdoors, spyware, or ransomware once executed, bypassing security by posing as trusted files.
trojan horse.use_case: A fake PDF invoice installs a Trojan that gives attackers remote access to a business laptop.

ransomware.eli5: Ransomware locks up your files and demands money to get them backâ€”like digital kidnapping.
ransomware.boss: Ransomware encrypts data and holds it hostage until the victim pays a ransom, often in cryptocurrency.
ransomware.sysadmin: It spreads via phishing or exploits, encrypting entire file systems, and sometimes exfiltrating data before ransom demands.
ransomware.use_case: A hospital pays Bitcoin to recover patient data locked by ransomware after a phishing attack.

spyware.eli5: Spyware is like someone secretly reading over your shoulder while you use your computer.
spyware.boss: Spyware is software that secretly monitors and collects information about a user without their knowledge.
spyware.sysadmin: Spyware installs quietly, tracking user activity, logging keystrokes, or harvesting browser data, often bundled with other software.
spyware.use_case: A compromised app installs spyware that logs user activity and sends it to attackers.

adware.eli5: Adware is like a pushy salesperson that wonâ€™t stop showing you adsâ€”even when you didnâ€™t ask.
adware.boss: Adware is software that displays unwanted advertisements, often bundled with free applications.
adware.sysadmin: Adware tracks user behavior to serve targeted ads, sometimes slowing systems or acting as a gateway for malware.
adware.use_case: A free game installs adware that displays pop-up ads even when the browser is closed.

rootkit.eli5: A rootkit is like an invisibility cloak for hackersâ€”it hides their tools inside your computer.
rootkit.boss: Rootkits are stealthy tools that hide malicious processes or files to help attackers maintain access.
rootkit.sysadmin: Rootkits operate at the kernel or user level to conceal malware, keyloggers, or backdoors, making them hard to detect.
rootkit.use_case: A rootkit hides a remote access Trojan on a compromised server, evading antivirus scans.

keylogger.eli5: A keylogger is like a hidden camera for your keyboardâ€”it records every key you press.
keylogger.boss: Keyloggers are tools that capture everything a user types, often to steal passwords or sensitive data.
keylogger.sysadmin: They run in the background, saving keystrokes to a log file, and may be part of spyware or advanced persistent threats.
keylogger.use_case: An attacker uses a keylogger to capture a userâ€™s bank login credentials.

logic bomb.eli5: A logic bomb is a digital prankâ€”or trapâ€”that explodes only when a specific thing happens.
logic bomb.boss: Logic bombs are hidden pieces of code that activate under certain conditions, often causing damage.
logic bomb.sysadmin: Theyâ€™re embedded in legitimate programs and triggered by events like date/time, user login, or file deletion.
logic bomb.use_case: A disgruntled employee plants a logic bomb that deletes critical files if they're fired.

backdoor.eli5: A backdoor is like a secret tunnel into your computer that someone else can sneak through.
backdoor.boss: Backdoors are hidden methods of bypassing normal authentication to access systems or data.
backdoor.sysadmin: Attackers use backdoors to gain persistent access after exploitation, often embedding them in malware or firmware.
backdoor.use_case: A hacker installs a backdoor on a web server to regain access even after their original exploit is patched.

fileless malware.eli5: Fileless malware is like a ghostâ€”it sneaks into your computer without leaving any files behind.
fileless malware.boss: Fileless malware infects systems by running directly in memory, making it harder to detect and remove.
fileless malware.sysadmin: It exploits trusted system tools like PowerShell or WMI to execute malicious code without writing files to disk.
fileless malware.use_case: An attacker uses a phishing link to launch fileless malware that exfiltrates browser data in memory.

botnet.eli5: A botnet is like an army of hacked computers being remote-controlled to do bad things.
botnet.boss: A botnet is a group of compromised devices controlled by an attacker to perform coordinated cyberattacks.
botnet.sysadmin: Botnets are managed via command-and-control servers and used for DDoS, spam, or credential stuffing campaigns.
botnet.use_case: A massive botnet floods a target with traffic, causing a major website to go offline.

phishing.eli5: Phishing is like a scammy email pretending to be someone you trust so youâ€™ll click or share secrets.
phishing.boss: Phishing is a cyberattack that uses fake messages to trick users into giving away sensitive information.
phishing.sysadmin: Phishing emails spoof trusted brands or people to steal credentials, deliver malware, or collect payment info.
phishing.use_case: An employee clicks a phishing email that looks like it came from their bank and enters login details.

spear phishing.eli5: Spear phishing is like phishing, but personalizedâ€”itâ€™s written just for you.
spear phishing.boss: Spear phishing targets specific individuals or organizations with customized, convincing scam messages.
spear phishing.sysadmin: Attackers use personal information (e.g., name, role, recent activity) to make the scam look legitimate and bypass suspicion.
spear phishing.use_case: A CFO receives a spear phishing email disguised as a request from the CEO to transfer funds.

whaling.eli5: Whaling is phishing aimed at the big fishâ€”like the CEO or high-up execs.
whaling.boss: Whaling targets top executives using highly tailored phishing tactics to steal credentials or authorize fraudulent transactions.
whaling.sysadmin: Whaling emails mimic executive-level correspondence and may include fake legal notices or financial documents.
whaling.use_case: A fake subpoena email tricks a company president into downloading ransomware.

smishing.eli5: Smishing is phishing through text messagesâ€”scammy SMS that try to fool you.
smishing.boss: Smishing uses SMS or messaging apps to deceive users into clicking malicious links or revealing private information.
smishing.sysadmin: Smishing attacks may impersonate banks, carriers, or delivery services and often include shortened URLs to mask intent.
smishing.use_case: A user gets a text claiming their package is delayed, but the link installs spyware.

vishing.eli5: Vishing is voice phishingâ€”scammers calling you pretending to be someone trustworthy.
vishing.boss: Vishing uses phone calls to trick victims into sharing personal or financial information.
vishing.sysadmin: Vishing attacks often spoof caller IDs and use urgency or fear to elicit confidential responses.
vishing.use_case: An attacker pretends to be IT support and convinces an employee to share their login password.

social engineering.eli5: Social engineering is when bad guys trick people, not computers, to get what they want.
social engineering.boss: Social engineering manipulates human behavior to gain access to systems, data, or physical locations.
social engineering.sysadmin: Tactics include phishing, pretexting, tailgating, and baitingâ€”often exploiting trust, fear, or urgency.
social engineering.use_case: An attacker talks their way past front desk security by pretending to be from IT.

credential stuffing.eli5: Credential stuffing is when hackers try your leaked username and password on a bunch of other sites.
credential stuffing.boss: Credential stuffing uses stolen login credentials from one site to break into others where users reused them.
credential stuffing.sysadmin: Automated tools test credential pairs across services, exploiting weak password habits and data breaches.
credential stuffing.use_case: A hacker uses breached passwords from a gaming site to access email and bank accounts.

brute force attack.eli5: Brute force is guessing passwords over and over until something worksâ€”like trying every key on a keyring.
brute force attack.boss: A brute force attack repeatedly attempts different username/password combinations to gain unauthorized access.
brute force attack.sysadmin: Brute force tools cycle through millions of password guesses, often countered with rate limits or MFA.
brute force attack.use_case: An attacker runs a brute force script against a serverâ€™s SSH login to gain root access.

password spraying.eli5: Instead of trying lots of passwords on one account, password spraying tries one password on lots of accounts.
password spraying.boss: Password spraying is a type of brute force attack that avoids lockouts by testing common passwords across many accounts.
password spraying.sysadmin: Spraying attacks slowly cycle through passwords like 'Winter2024!' across a wide list of usernames to stay under detection thresholds.
password spraying.use_case: A hacker uses password spraying against corporate email accounts with common passwords like 'Welcome1'.

man-in-the-middle.eli5: A man-in-the-middle is like someone secretly listening and changing the messages between two people passing notes.
man-in-the-middle.boss: A MITM attack intercepts and possibly alters communications between two parties without their knowledge.
man-in-the-middle.sysadmin: MITM exploits include session hijacking, SSL stripping, and DNS spoofing to eavesdrop or inject data in transit.
man-in-the-middle.use_case: An attacker on public Wi-Fi captures unencrypted credentials via a man-in-the-middle attack.

wifi.eli5: Wi-Fi is how your gadgets connect to the internet without any wires.
wifi.boss: Wi-Fi is a wireless networking technology that allows devices to communicate and access the internet.
wifi.sysadmin: Wi-Fi uses IEEE 802.11 protocols over 2.4 GHz and 5 GHz bands, with WPA-based security and dynamic channel selection.
wifi.use_case: A user sets up a Wi-Fi mesh system to get strong wireless coverage in every room.

wyze.eli5: Wyze makes smart home gadgets that donâ€™t cost a fortuneâ€”like cameras and lights you can control with your phone.
wyze.boss: Wyze is a consumer tech company offering affordable smart home devices including cameras, sensors, and lighting.
wyze.sysadmin: Wyze devices connect via Wi-Fi and integrate with Alexa, Google Assistant, and the Wyze app using cloud APIs or local control in beta.
wyze.use_case: A user installs Wyze cameras to monitor their home and get motion alerts on their phone.

zigbee.eli5: Zigbee is like a walkie-talkie language smart devices use to talk to each other nearby.
zigbee.boss: Zigbee is a wireless protocol used for low-power, short-range communication between smart home devices.
zigbee.sysadmin: Zigbee operates in the 2.4GHz band, forming a mesh network for sensors, lights, and switches with low bandwidth needs.
zigbee.use_case: A smart home hub controls Zigbee lights and motion sensors without needing Wi-Fi.

zwave.eli5: Z-Wave is like Zigbeeâ€™s cousinâ€”another way smart home devices talk to each other wirelessly.
zwave.boss: Z-Wave is a wireless protocol for smart home automation that focuses on range, reliability, and low interference.
zwave.sysadmin: Z-Wave uses sub-1GHz frequencies for mesh networking, reducing interference with Wi-Fi and enabling long-range, low-power communication.
zwave.use_case: A Z-Wave-enabled lock syncs with a smart hub to automate home security.

yale assure lock.eli5: The Yale Assure Lock is a smart door lockâ€”you can unlock it with your phone, code, or voice.
yale assure lock.boss: The Yale Assure Lock is a keyless smart lock that integrates with home automation systems for secure entry control.
yale assure lock.sysadmin: It supports Wi-Fi, Z-Wave, Zigbee, or Matter depending on the model, with mobile apps, automations, and remote access.
yale assure lock.use_case: A homeowner installs a Yale Assure Lock that auto-unlocks when their phone approaches the door.

yaml automation.eli5: YAML automation is like writing recipes for your tech to followâ€”just with clean, easy-to-read text.
yaml automation.boss: YAML automation uses YAML files to define repeatable processes for configuration, orchestration, or integration workflows.
yaml automation.sysadmin: YAML is used in platforms like Ansible, Home Assistant, GitHub Actions, and Kubernetes to declaratively describe states and actions.
yaml automation.use_case: A smart home user writes a YAML automation to turn off all lights and lock doors at midnight.
